Navigation

Because the navigation of a website can be such an integral part of its unique design, we've done our best to keep top-level menu styling as simple as possible, for easy CSS extending.

However, one of the most notable features of our navigation menus is the support for dropdown (or "fly-out") menus, which are always triggered with a hover state. This is done with custom styling and JavaScript from the Front Street framework. When building the navigational elements discussed in this article, you can add support for our dropdown script by simply adding the class fs-menu.

And for any of the navigation bars, if you'd like to utilize Front Street for coloring them, use any of the color classes to set a background color and classes text-light and text-dark to adjust the text.

Primary Navigation

For a basic navigation bar, create an unordered list of links with class navbar. You can also nest additional second-level and third-level unordered lists within for submenus. And for all levels, make sure to add class menu-btn to any link <a> tags.

Vertical Primary Navigation

By default, the .navbar element is inherently vertical and will fill the width of its current container.

In the following example, we've got an unordered list with with class navbar added. For coloring, the classes bg-light and text-dark have been added. Also, an example of a second-level and third-level menu has been nested within.

  • Home
  • About
    • Philosophy
    • Brand
    • History
    • Team
      • Bob
      • Joe
      • Tom
  • Services
  • News
  • Contact
<ul class="navbar bg-light text-dark">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
			
    • 
				Team
				
        
					
      • Bob
        • 
					
      • Joe
        • 
					
      • Tom
        • 
				
      
			
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And next, we've altered the markup from above to include the primary branding background color class and text-light to lighten the text.

    • Home

    Dropdown Menus

    And to present those second-level and third-level menus as dropdown (or "fly-out") menus, add the class fs-menu to the .navbar element. — And for fun, this time we've added the classes red and text-light for coloring.

    • Home
    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • History
      • Team
        • Bob
        • Joe
        • Tom
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="navbar fs-menu red text-light">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  •

    • Brand

    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And an additional feature available when working with a .fs-menu element is that you can use these color classes on the second-level and third-level submenus, as well; so you'll see we've expanded on the previous example to include classes crimson and text-light to the submenus.

    Horizontal Primary Navigation

    Because the .navbar element is inherently vertical with stacked buttons, we need to add an additional class to align the buttons in a horizontal bar. You can use classes navbar-horz, navbar-horz-xs, navbar-horz-sm, navbar-horz-md, or navbar-horz-lg (see responsiveness below for more on which class you'd use).

    • Home
    • About
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="navbar navbar-horz bg-light text-dark">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  • About
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And again, we can use whichever color classes we want. This next example is the same as above, but with classes primary and text-light used.

    • Home
    • About
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="navbar navbar-horz-sm primary text-light">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  • About
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    Dropdown Menus

    When working with a horizontal .navbar, you'll need to also add the fs-menu class to include any second-level and third-level submenus. And this will present them as dropdown (or "fly-out") menus. — And for fun, this time we've added the classes royal and text-light for coloring.

    And when working with a horizontal .navbar with submenus, you must add color classes to the nested submenus. You'll notice in the following example we've added classes dark_blue and text-light to those nested unordered lists.

    • Home
    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • History
      • Team
        • Bob
        • Joe
        • Tom
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="navbar navbar-horz-sm fs-menu royal text-light">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
			
    • 
				Team
				
        
					
      • Bob
        • 
					
      • Joe
        • 
					
      • Tom
        • 
				
      
			
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    Note: If you don't want a menu link to be clickable by the user, you can add the class no-click. You'll see this used in the example above to make the top-level "About" menu item not clickable.

    Secondary Navigation

    For a basic secondary navigation bar with a slightly altered look from the primary navigation bar, create an unordered list of links with class subnav. You can also nest additional second-level and third-level unordered lists within for submenus. And for all levels, make sure to add class menu-btn to any link <a> tags.

    Vertical Secondary Navigation

    By default, the .subnav element is inherently vertical and will fill the width of its current container.

    In the following example, we've got an unordered list with with class subnav added. For coloring, the classes bg-light and text-dark have been added. Also, an example of a second-level and third-level menu has been nested within.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav bg-light text-dark">
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • Team
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And again, we can use whichever color classes we want. This next example is the same as above, but with classes primary and text-light used.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav primary text-light">
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • Team
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    Dropdown Menus

    If you'd like submenus to have the dropdown (or "fly-out") effect, you can add class fs-menu. — And to mix things up, we've adjusted the color classes from the previous example, as well.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav fs-menu jungle text-light">
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • Team
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And an additional feature available when working with a .fs-menu element is that you can use these color classes on the second-level and third-level submenus, as well; so you'll see we've expanded on the previous example to include classes black and text-light to the submenu.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav fs-menu jungle text-light">
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • Team
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services

</ul>

    Horizontal Secondary Navigation

    Because the .subnav element is inherently vertical with stacked buttons, we need to add an additional class to align the buttons in a horizontal bar. You can use classes subnav-horz, subnav-horz-xs, subnav-horz-sm, subnav-horz-md, or subnav-horz-lg (see responsiveness below for more on which class you'd use).

    • About
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav subnav-horz-sm bg-light text-dark">
	
  • About
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And again, we can use whichever color classes we want. This next example is the same as above, but with classes primary and text-light used.

    • About
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav subnav-horz-sm primary text-light">
	
  • About
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    Dropdown Menus

    When working with a horizontal .subnav, you'll need to also add the fs-menu class to include any second-level and third-level submenus. And this will present them as dropdown (or "fly-out") menus. — And for fun, this time we've added the classes dark_purple and text-light for coloring.

    And when working with a horizontal .subnav with submenus, you must add color classes to the nested submenus. You'll notice in the following example we've added classes pink and text-light to that nested unordered list.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav subnav-horz-sm fs-menu dark_purple text-light">

    Responsiveness

    From above, you know that to make your .navbar and .subnav menus display horizontally, you can add the classe navbar-horz and subnav-horz. However, this doesn't account for any responsiveness.

    So instead, to make your menus responsive, you can utilize one of the navbar-horz-* or subnav-horz-* classes to specify a stacking point. This works similarly to the grid system and determining your stacking point there.

    .navbar-horz Classes containing no breakpoint will never stack. This is not recommended in most cases and especially not recommended if your menu includes submenus.
    .subnav-horz
    .navbar-horz-xs Classes containing xs will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 576px. This will generally include smaller mobile devices.
    .subnav-horz-xs
    .navbar-horz-sm Classes containing sm will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 768px. This will generally include slightly larger mobile devices (or those in the landscape orientation) and smaller mobile devices.
    .subnav-horz-sm
    .navbar-horz-md Classes containing md will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 992px. This will generally include tablets (in portrait orientation) and any mobile device smaller than that.
    .subnav-horz-md
    .navbar-horz-lg Classes containing lg will collapse and begin to stack when viewport is less than 1200px. This will generally include smaller desktop computers, and all tablets and mobile devices.
    .subnav-horz-lg

    In the following example, we've got a .navbar element as we've discussed above, but now the class navbar-horz-md has been used instead of navbar-horz. And so this means the menu will stack when the viewport is less than 992px.

    • Home
    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • History
      • Team
        • Bob
        • Joe
        • Tom
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="navbar navbar-horz-md fs-menu primary text-light">
	
  • Home
    • 
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
			
    • 
				Team
				
        
					
      • Bob
        • 
					
      • Joe
        • 
					
      • Tom
        • 
				
      
			
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    And in this example, the class subnav-horz-sm has been used with the .subnav element. This means it will stack when the viewport is less than 768px.

    • About
      • Philosophy
      • Brand
      • Team
      • History
    • Services
    • News
    • Contact
    <ul class="subnav subnav-horz-sm fs-menu bg-light text-dark">
	
  • 
		About
		
      
			
    • Philosophy
      • 
			
    • Brand
      • 
			
    • Team
      • 
			
    • History
      • 
		
    
	
    • 
	
  • Services
    • 
	
  • News
    • 
	
  • Contact
    • 
</ul>

    Breadcrumbs

    The following is an example of how to format an unordered list with class fs-breadcrumbs added.

    • Home
    • Parent Page
    • Current Page
      
	
    • Home
      • 
	
    • Parent Page
      • 
	
    • Current Page
      •

    If you'd like your .fs-breadcrumbs element to be contained within a block with background color, make sure to also add your color class, class text-light or text-dark, and class has-bg.

    • Home
    • Parent Page
    • Current Page
      
	
    • Home
      • 
	
    • Parent Page
      • 
	
    • Current Page

    • Current Page
